title: How Across Protocol is looking to fix crypto's cross-chain headaches

rawLines.text: [Music]
Hello and welcome to the Cryptobe. My
name is Tim Copeland, Nblock's head of
growth. Joining me today, we have the
co-founder of Across Protocol, Al
Lambert. Welcome to the show. How are
you doing? Hey Tim, thanks for having
me. Doing great. Really appreciate you
having me on. Brilliant. Before we get
started, just a quick note. If you're
hiring a crypto, you should check out
Campus. Out of all of your candidates,
help you pick out the real crypto native
hires. Uh head to the block.co/campus to
get a 3month free trial. Now today's
episode is about going crosschain. Um so
what is a cross protocol in a nutshell?
A cross protocol is uh cloally it's
known as a fast bridge. A way to move
assets like really quickly within a
couple seconds between blockchains. Um
what we more technically it's uh this
intentbased bridging protocol where we
sort of shortcut traditional bridges and
use thirdparty actors which we'll get
into uh called relay solvers or market
makers to front you assets to just
basically make two chains seem like
they're seamlessly connected. If it's is
enabling swaps that are that fast are
there any compromises that you make in
order to do that or have you just you
know found this amazing solution? Well
there are trade-offs right? So, I mean,
it's worth the way I typically like to
kind of frame it is, okay, I got two
blockchains. I'll link it A and B. I'll
call it arbitum and base. Um, and these
two blockchains are not really
connected. They're connected through
Ethereum, but they're connected through
Ethereum through like a 7-day bridge
technically. Um, and some other
blockchains, you know, aren't connected
at all. And, uh, you want to like move
assets between the two of them. How do
you do it? So, I mean, backing up and
kind of giving a framework here, the
naive way of how you would connect these
two blockchains is you like maybe have a
pool of assets on chain A. You send
something to a contract on chain A and
then some message gets sent over to
chain B and then assets get released on
chain B. Um, and you could maybe those
assets are burnt on one chain and minted
on the other and you're introducing like
security assumptions there or maybe you
have like pools of assets on both sides.
Um, but the general problem with that is
you have to like send this message for
each transfer and that message is slow.
Not only because like you have to send
the message, but you also can't send
that message until you have a sense of
finality on the origin chain. Um, so
more precisely, it's like if that
message is like wrong on the origin
chain, you end up just like poof
creating money on the destination chain
and the whole thing breaks. So a lot of
like a lot of bridges, a lot of
traditional bridges, they're relatively
slow here because of this problem
because like you can't just poof create
assets uh and like you know the asset
issuer just like loses money. So like
what's the solution here? What's the
trade-off? Um the intentbased approach
does something different. So on chain A,
we take the user's assets and we put
them into basically an escrow contract.
So they're locked up and then we start a
race for third-party solvers who are
going to go and fill the user on the
destination chain with their own money
and those solvers are going to be the
ones that take on the reorg or finality
risk. Um but they're sophisticated
actors. They know how to price this.
They know what that risk is and they
race to fill the user with their own
money. User gets filled like L2 to L2 or
like two second fill times. user gets
filled extremely quickly on the
destination chain and they move on with
their day and then the protocol will
like verify the fill happened before it
releases the user assets back to the
solver. So basically we're introducing
like third-party semi-sophisticated
actors to provide this like liquidity
network that connects these chains and
does it very quickly. Does that make any
sense? Yeah. How does it work in terms
of them filling the assets? like if I'm
a solver and I see this person, you
know, that there's opportunity there, do
I just send them my money and hope I'm
first? Like, you know, like obviously
that that's a stupid idea. So, I assume
it works differently. It's sort of
stupid, but sort of not. Like, uh, in
essence, uh, like if you and I are both
solvers and we see an opportunity, so
Jordan, your producer, right? He wants
to send money from A to B. He puts money
in chain A. Um, and we're like, "Okay,
cool. Let's go race." There's a contract
on chain B that you and I are both going
to try to be first to send money
through. So, we're just going to send
money through this contract to Jordan,
but like it's the transaction's nons.
So, we like know it's Jordan's
transaction, and the first one of us to
send a money uh gets the fee associated
with that bridge. The second person just
doesn't get to like the transaction will
revert and it won't let them send money
through. So, okay. Yeah, you're kind of
right. We're basically just racing. Um,
and like we can go a lot deeper and um,
should we be competing on speed? Should
we be competing on price? Should we be
competing on a combination of the two of
them? It can get really interesting on
how you structure this, but the highle
argument is like, yeah, we're going to
see who has the first person to be able
to do this according to the constraints
of the quote unquote intent, what you
know, the the user is intending to do.
First person wins.
Interesting. It sort of seems kind of
similar to um transfer wise or I believe
they're now called wise um where like
they like instead of swapping money
they'll just have buckets on each side
and then they just reallocate on each
side and that just avoids actually
swapping the chain. There's a lot of uh
kind of examples that relate to yeah
transfer wise even like traditional
remittance like Western Union like way
old school business Western Union uh you
go in the UK and you want to send money
to the Philippines you like give them
money they're not doing an international
wire transfer to the Philippines which
is expensive and crazy slow instead
they're going to like send the user in
the Philippines money um and then later
on they'll rebalance between the their
bank accounts in the Philipp they'll do
thousands of these and then they'll re
rebalance once a week between their bank
account in the Philippines and the bank
account in the UK and send like a wire
transfer and like that analogy Tim is
actually pretty close to what a cross
and intentbased bridges are doing with
all the traditional like the slow
canonical bridges in Ethereum. So if we
go back to our example with like blit
base and arbitrum I can connect those
two chains canonically using a 7-day
bridge. It's just really slow. So the
solvers are doing this like fast thing
with their own money between the chains
and then they're using the slow bridges
or maybe centralized exchanges or
whatever other method they want to
rebalance those assets periodically.
Who decides the fee? Do they get to
choose their own fees? Like how does
that work? Really good question. Um the
fee right now is is set by the protocol.
I mean technically the user can type in
whatever fee they want but solvers might
not like fill them. They might say
that's too low, which does happen. But
the fee is set by the protocol that's
saying here's what we think the market
clearing rate is uh for this route. Um
and solvers are competing on that. Lots
of ideas on how we can like ek more
performance by having an auction there
too, you know, like hey, what is the uh
let's have solvers compete. But again,
it's kind of interesting. Do we are we
preferencing costs or speed right now?
like right now we're having everybody
race to fill for a set fee um versus
trying to fill at the lowest possible
price. There's potentially cool ways in
the relatively near future we might do
both. Um but yeah, that that's the way
it's working today. And it works pretty
well because the fees are so low like
the costs here are really pretty
microscopic that the costs aren't really
the issue. Instead, what across and
intentbased systems I think are what
we're really delivering that's like the
unique value prop is speed. like how do
we make these two chains feel like one
by connecting them in two seconds.
Are you finding much success in terms of
number of like uh I guess amount of
money flowing through the protocol
compared to other bridging uh solutions?
Yeah. Um we are uh I think like process
has been around for a few years now. Um
sort of really two-ish years ago was
when I think we started growing rapidly.
Um, and we are uh like one of, if
depending on how you look at it, like
the most used bridge for moving Ethereum
around by by volume. Um, but we
actually, and it's worth digging into,
we're most much more focused on the
number of transactions we do. um because
there's there's a few big transactions
that move huge volume which which is
great but for the vast vast majority of
users you know using Ethereum using web
3 they're not moving around
million-dollar transfers or $2 million
trades they're moving around you know
100 bucks 500 bucks 10 grand um the the
the median um transfer size that we see
is about about 100 bucks right now and
that's like the sweet spot so we are
really dominating in uh the number of
transfers we're sending between these
chains and seeing a lot of traction
there. And did you have any experience
with this sort of as you shifted into
crypto? I know you worked like Goldman
Sachs for quite a few years an investor.
Um like how did you end up doing this?
Yeah. Um okay. So going back like the
first thing I did out of college was
work as a bond trader like treasury bond
trader at Goldman. um did that in New
York for eight years during the
financial crisis. Um and there are
actually some analogies towards how a
cross works versus how uh bond trading
works here too. Um
if you think of the the treasury market,
you have uh customers that are going to
go ask uh primary dealers. So Goldman,
JP Morgan, Deutsche Bank, whatever else,
they asked them like, "Hey, where can I
sell a 100red million 10ear treasuries?"
like this was literally my job and um
it's a request for quote style system
where the solvers or the solvers the the
trading desks compete to say here Tim my
price is this and you know Deutsche Bank
says their price is that and you say
okay I'm going to trade with Goldman
they gave me the best price um and this
kind of uh request for quote style
system is sort of what's going on in
across here in some ways it's kind of
like the onchain uh
version of it where that that kind of
like Tradfi version the rules are
ambiguous like you can kind of they're a
little squishy the rules which leads to
people accusing each other of like doing
bad things and effectively in across
we've taken a lot of those concepts said
okay instead of it being you know
trading desks we've got solvers and the
rules are completely transparent and
clear on chain um and we can have this
like fair and efficient competition to
solve this problem of connecting these
chains. Yeah, that makes sense. Uh and
you mentioned intense earlier.
Obviously, this was quite a big
discussion point um sort of over like
the last year or so.
What like how do you use them or at
least like what are you trying to enable
with them?
Lots lots to unpack there. So, we are in
many ways the original intense protocol
or at least the original intense
protocol that got used. And so I've had
a I've done a lot to push this this kind
of concept. Um our team has done a lot
to push this concept forward. And like
what does this sort of buzzword mean? I
mean I don't want it to be a buzz word.
I want it to be real. Um it just
basically means like hey what are you
trying to do? What is the outcome you
want on the destination chain? Um, if
the outcome I want is I want I want to
like I'm starting here with like 50 USDC
on chain A and I want as much USDC as I
can on chain B. Okay, cool. My intent is
give me max USDC on chain B. If my
outcome is I actually want to take my
max USDC and deposit into a that I can
specify too. And the intent concept
basically works really really well in
this multi-chain world where I can say
what I'm looking to do is have this
action this this transaction completed
on this destination chain. Um who wants
to do it for me? And that's that's the
core concept. So we and when you have
this multi-chain world in order to make
this be fast there really is no other
architecture than having these solvers
compete to do that action. So we we put
together a standard for this uh ERC7683.
None of your readers are going to
remember 7683 but that's uh the
listeners I should say that's the
number. We wrote this with unis swap
co-authored this standard with unis swap
and it's been actually really pretty
broadly adopted um as a standard

specify these crosschain intents. And
then how does that work for the user? Is
it that you go on to like a website and
it's and it sort of gives you options.
It's like you put drop down list, you
say I want to swap this to this and this
protocol and this chain or is it like
text space? You just write it out. Like
what's that what's that experience like?
So the front end experience can kind of
be any of those things. Um what the user
technically does is sign a message that
specifies their intent on the origin
chain. So all they have to do is like
sign a message on the origin chain. how
you that that says here's what I want to
do on the destination chain. Um
practically speaking like if you go to

100 A a to B hit send and you sign a

Here's what I want to do. Um, that gets

Here's the user's intent. They sign that

there's stuff we can talk about too once

smart contracts everywhere which is

with the Pectra hard fork and um this

going to have the ability where user's

Here's the permission to action I want

my intent is basically who wants to
here's my signed message that proves I

contract um wallet. Um who who here
wants to go and fill it? So, it's pretty

user has a transaction they want to have

intent is the way to uh to specify that.
And how far before all of this is

in a very nice user experience? Like are

you know the user
maybe it's a a vault product or

then has all of this puts into Ave on

um you know unis swap integrated across

But there's lots and lots of this. Um
there's other like yield protocols that

you can imagine that they integrate

I'm starting from arbitr but I want to

Um, so maybe like the right mental model
to push to the the listeners and and

I've been toying with this a little bit.
Think of it as like uh like like it's
like a checkout at Amazon where I'm

and I think the right experience is the

Um, and the the user also doesn't have

I think that we're we'll have examples

So, it's like very good point. Like

Hello and welcome to the Cryptobe. My name is Tim Copeland, The Block's head of growth. Joining me today, we have the co-founder of Across Protocol, Hart Lambur. Welcome to the show. How are you doing? Hey Tim, thanks for having me. Doing great. Really appreciate you having me on. Brilliant. Before we get started, just a quick note. If you're hiring in crypto, you should check out Campus. Out of all of your candidates, help you pick out the real crypto native hires. Head to theblock.co/campus to get a 3-month free trial. Now today's episode is about going cross-chain. So what is a cross-chain protocol in a nutshell?

A cross-chain protocol is, colloquially, it's known as a fast bridge. A way to move assets like really quickly within a couple seconds between blockchains. What we more technically, it's this intent-based bridging protocol where we sort of shortcut traditional bridges and use third-party actors, which we'll get into, called relay solvers or market makers to front you assets to just basically make two chains seem like they're seamlessly connected. If it's enabling swaps that are that fast, are there any compromises that you make in order to do that, or have you just, you know, found this amazing solution?

Well, there are trade-offs, right? So, I mean, it's worth the way I typically like to kind of frame it is, okay, I got two blockchains. I'll link it A and B. I'll call it Arbitrum and Base. And these two blockchains are not really connected. They're connected through Ethereum, but they're connected through Ethereum through like a 7-day bridge technically. And some other blockchains, you know, aren't connected at all. And you want to like move assets between the two of them. How do you do it? So, I mean, backing up and kind of giving a framework here, the naive way of how you would connect these two blockchains is you like maybe have a pool of assets on chain A. You send something to a contract on chain A, and then some message gets sent over to chain B, and then assets get released on chain B. And you could maybe those assets are burnt on one chain and minted on the other, and you're introducing like security assumptions there, or maybe you have like pools of assets on both sides. But the general problem with that is you have to like send this message for each transfer, and that message is slow. Not only because like you have to send the message, but you also can't send that message until you have a sense of finality on the origin chain. So more precisely, it's like if that message is like wrong on the origin chain, you end up just like poof creating money on the destination chain, and the whole thing breaks. So a lot of bridges, a lot of traditional bridges, they're relatively slow here because of this problem, because like you can't just poof create assets, and like, you know, the asset issuer just like loses money. So like what's the solution here? What's the trade-off? The intent-based approach does something different. So on chain A, we take the user's assets and we put them into basically an escrow contract. So they're locked up, and then we start a race for third-party solvers who are going to go and fill the user on the destination chain with their own money, and those solvers are going to be the ones that take on the reorg or finality risk. But they're sophisticated actors. They know how to price this. They know what that risk is, and they race to fill the user with their own money. User gets filled, like L2 to L2 or like two-second fill times. User gets filled extremely quickly on the destination chain, and they move on with their day, and then the protocol will like verify the fill happened before it releases the user assets back to the solver. So basically, we're introducing like third-party semi-sophisticated actors to provide this like liquidity network that connects these chains and does it very quickly. Does that make any sense?

Yeah. How does it work in terms of them filling the assets? Like if I'm a solver and I see this person, you know, that there's opportunity there, do I just send them my money and hope I'm first? Like, you know, like obviously that that's a stupid idea. So, I assume it works differently. It's sort of stupid, but sort of not. Like, in essence, like if you and I are both solvers and we see an opportunity, so Jordan, your producer, right? He wants to send money from A to B. He puts money in chain A. And we're like, "Okay, cool. Let's go race." There's a contract on chain B that you and I are both going to try to be first to send money through. So, we're just going to send money through this contract to Jordan, but like it's the transaction's nons. So, we like know it's Jordan's transaction, and the first one of us to send a money gets the fee associated with that bridge. The second person just doesn't get to, like the transaction will revert and it won't let them send money through. So, okay. Yeah, you're kind of right. We're basically just racing. And like we can go a lot deeper and should we be competing on speed? Should we be competing on price? Should we be competing on a combination of the two of them? It can get really interesting on how you structure this, but the high-level argument is like, yeah, we're going to see who has the first person to be able to do this according to the constraints of the quote unquote intent, what you know, the user is intending to do. First person wins.

Interesting. It sort of seems kind of similar to TransferWise, or I believe they're now called Wise, where like they like instead of swapping money, they'll just have buckets on each side and then they just reallocate on each side, and that just avoids actually swapping the chain. There's a lot of kind of examples that relate to, yeah, TransferWise, even like traditional remittance, like Western Union, like way old school business. Western Union, you go in the UK and you want to send money to the Philippines, you like give them money, they're not doing an international wire transfer to the Philippines, which is expensive and crazy slow. Instead, they're going to like send the user in the Philippines money, and then later on they'll rebalance between their bank accounts in the Philipp, they'll do thousands of these, and then they'll rebalance once a week between their bank account in the Philippines and the bank account in the UK and send like a wire transfer. And like that analogy, Tim, is actually pretty close to what a cross and intent-based bridges are doing with all the traditional, like the slow canonical bridges in Ethereum. So if we go back to our example with like Base and Arbitrum, I can connect those two chains canonically using a 7-day bridge. It's just really slow. So the solvers are doing this like fast thing with their own money between the chains, and then they're using the slow bridges or maybe centralized exchanges or whatever other method they want to rebalance those assets periodically.

Who decides the fee? Do they get to choose their own fees? Like how does that work? Really good question. The fee right now is set by the protocol. I mean, technically the user can type in whatever fee they want, but solvers might not like fill them. They might say that's too low, which does happen. But the fee is set by the protocol that's saying here's what we think the market clearing rate is for this route. And solvers are competing on that. Lots of ideas on how we can like ek more performance by having an auction there too, you know, like, hey, what is the, let's have solvers compete. But again, it's kind of interesting. Do we, are we preferencing costs or speed right now? Like right now we're having everybody race to fill for a set fee versus trying to fill at the lowest possible price. There's potentially cool ways in the relatively near future we might do both. But yeah, that that's the way it's working today. And it works pretty well because the fees are so low, like the costs here are really pretty microscopic that the costs aren't really the issue. Instead, what Across and intent-based systems, I think, are what we're really delivering that's like the unique value prop is speed. Like how do we make these two chains feel like one by connecting them in two seconds?

Are you finding much success in terms of number of, like, I guess amount of money flowing through the protocol compared to other bridging solutions? Yeah. We are. I think Across has been around for a few years now. Sort of really two-ish years ago was when I think we started growing rapidly. And we are, like one of, if, depending on how you look at it, like the most used bridge for moving Ethereum around by volume. But we actually, and it's worth digging into, we're much more focused on the number of transactions we do, because there's a few big transactions that move huge volume, which is great, but for the vast, vast majority of users, you know, using Ethereum, using web3, they're not moving around million-dollar transfers or $2 million trades, they're moving around, you know, 100 bucks, 500 bucks, 10 grand. The median transfer size that we see is about 100 bucks right now, and that's like the sweet spot. So we are really dominating in the number of transfers we're sending between these chains and seeing a lot of traction there. And did you have any experience with this sort of, as you shifted into crypto? I know you worked like Goldman Sachs for quite a few years, an investor. Like how did you end up doing this?

Yeah. Okay. So going back, like the first thing I did out of college was work as a bond trader, like treasury bond trader at Goldman. Did that in New York for eight years during the financial crisis. And there are actually some analogies towards how Across works versus how bond trading works here too. If you think of the treasury market, you have customers that are going to go ask primary dealers. So Goldman, JP Morgan, Deutsche Bank, whatever else, they asked them like, "Hey, where can I sell a 100 million 10-year treasuries?" Like this was literally my job, and it's a request for quote style system where the solvers or the solvers, the trading desks compete to say, here Tim, my price is this, and you know, Deutsche Bank says their price is that, and you say, okay, I'm going to trade with Goldman, they gave me the best price. And this kind of request for quote style system is sort of what's going on in Across here in some ways. It's kind of like the on-chain version of it where that kind of like TradFi version, the rules are ambiguous, like you can kind of, they're a little squishy, the rules, which leads to people accusing each other of like doing bad things, and effectively in Across, we've taken a lot of those concepts, said, okay, instead of it being, you know, trading desks, we've got solvers, and the rules are completely transparent and clear on chain, and we can have this like fair and efficient competition to solve this problem of connecting these chains.

Yeah, that makes sense. And you mentioned Intents earlier. Obviously, this was quite a big discussion point sort of over like the last year or so. What, like how do you use them, or at least like what are you trying to enable with them? Lots, lots to unpack there. So, we are in many ways the original Intents protocol, or at least the original Intents protocol that got used. And so I've had a, I've done a lot to push this, this kind of concept. Our team has done a lot to push this concept forward. And like what does this sort of buzzword mean? I mean, I don't want it to be a buzzword. I want it to be real. It just basically means like, hey, what are you trying to do? What is the outcome you want on the destination chain? If the outcome I want is I want, I want to like, I'm starting here with like 50 USDC on chain A, and I want as much USDC as I can on chain B. Okay, cool. My intent is give me max USDC on chain B. If my outcome is I actually want to take my max USDC and deposit into a, that I can specify too. And the intent concept basically works really, really well in this multi-chain world where I can say what I'm looking to do is have this action, this, this transaction completed on this destination chain. Who wants to do it for me? And that's that's the core concept. So we, and when you have this multi-chain world, in order to make this be fast, there really is no other architecture than having these solvers compete to do that action. So we, we put together a standard for this, ERC7683. None of your readers are going to remember 7683, but that's the listeners, I should say, that's the number. We wrote this with Uniswap, co-authored this standard with Uniswap, and it's been actually really pretty broadly adopted as a standard specification for how to like create and specify these cross-chain Intents.

And then how does that work for the user? Is it that you go on to like a website and it's and it sort of gives you options? It's like you put drop-down list, you say I want to swap this to this and this protocol and this chain, or is it like text space? You just write it out. Like what's that, what's that experience like? So the front-end experience can kind of be any of those things. What the user technically does is sign a message that specifies their intent on the origin chain. So all they have to do is like sign a message on the origin chain. How you, that that says here's what I want to do on the destination chain. Practically speaking, like if you go to the Across front end today, across.2, it looks like a bridge. You say I want to move 100 USDC from A to B, from Arbitrum to Base. You like click the buttons, 100 A to B, hit send, and you sign a message, and that's where the int, the intent is created by the app. But like, yeah, we've got like hackathons where people do the same thing in text form. I type out natural language. Here's what I want to do. That gets interpreted probably by like an LLM. Here's the user's intent. They sign that message, and they, they send it to the same network of solvers that we have today to go and like build that. There's stuff we can talk about too once we like move into this world of like smart contracts everywhere, which is happening nowish in Ethereum with with the Pectra hard fork and this upgrade called 7702. So, we're, we're going to have the ability where user's intent could be here is the action.


It's the permission to action I want to execute on the destination chain.
And my intent is basically who wants to, here's my signed message that proves I want to do this action in this smart contract wallet.
Um, who here wants to go and fill it?
So, it's pretty flexible, but it all distills back into a user has a transaction they want to have happen on the destination chain.
The intent is the way to uh to specify that.
And how far before all of this is completely hidden under the hood in a very nice user experience?
Like, are people building apps where the sort of, you know, the user, maybe it's a vault product or something, and then behind the scenes it then has all of this puts into Ave on this chain and all of that happens behind the scenes?
Yeah, it's happening.
Um, you know, Uniswap integrated Across in a way that lets you do crushing bridging in a way that you like the user doesn't really see because the intents are being specified behind the scenes.
It's probably like our the biggest most broadly used example of it.
But there's lots and lots of this.
Um, there's other like yield protocols that also say, hey, I need to have this deposit on Ethereum, but I want to make it accessible to the user to make this deposit from all the other L2s.
And so you can imagine that they integrate Across to just say my intent here is to, I'm starting from Arbitrum, but I want to end up with this vault deposit on Ethereum mainnet.
It's like a perfect use case.
Um, where I think this should go in many ways is it does go to the wallet level where wallets make it easy for applications.
They don't have to actually even like developers don't even have to specify any of this.
The wallet's just going to be like, "Hey, you're trying to execute this transaction on chain X and you don't actually have money on chain X, but I'm going to make it so you can pay for that transaction from chain A and all you have to do is like click this button."
Um, so maybe like the right mental model to push to the listeners and viewers is like, I've been toying with this a little bit.
Think of it as like uh like like it's like a checkout at Amazon where I'm trying to buy something.
The thing I'm trying to buy here is a transaction on a specific chain.
Um, but my payment options are I pay for it on A, I, B, pay for it on B, I pay for it on C, like whatever my payments options are.
And and I think the right experience is the wallet is going to abstract away and show you the payment option that makes the most sense uh for you.
So the developer doesn't have to do a thing.
The developer is just there.
It's like, here's what I want my application to do.
Um, and the user also doesn't have to overthink it.
The wallet is just being like, "Hey user, you're trying to do this thing.
Uh, here's the best way to pay for it."
